Posts.Title: Haematoma

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah I agree with Julia that you should ring your bc nurse. I had a haematoma, which is a blood clot and fluid and can give you flu like symptoms too, shortly after surgery. it couldn't be drained manually so i had surgery again to remove it (I was still in hospital at the time) that's not to say the same procedure will happen to you though. A couple of weeks later I had more fluid drained manually by my nurse, it was still a bit swollen after but felt so much better.  I hope you can get it sorted and please let us know how you get on.  Tilly xx

Posts.Title: Bi lateral masectomy with immediate construction - I'm terrified

Posts.Content: Hi cew i was a 36e (sometimes f depending on the style of the bra) after my op I started wearing 38dd so that the bra wasn't rubbing or pressing in to my scar, I had a softie originally in the "non boob" side but now that my expansion is finished I have gone down to a 38d. I still need to have an insert as my boobs are not the same size but this is fine for now. Perhaps you can try a different size or maybe even take the wire out of your normal bra So you can still wear your size? Not all my bras were mastectomy bras, as long as there was enough of the bra to cover the softie and hold it in. Hope this is of some help to you.  Tilly xx

Posts.Title: Home- post mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi i had the same as you and was very lucky that I didn't need chemo and radiotherapy, however I was still off from work for over 4 months due to lack of arm/shoulder movement and waiting to see whether I needed further treatment. My surgeon said it was ok for me to go back to work but only on phased return and mainly because I have a sit down office job. Again I have been lucky in that my work have been very supportive and still are (I need more time off next year for more ops) but they were very insistant that it was all done through the correct procedure ie: occupational health. i wasn't allowed back until I seen an occ health nurse and they had to assess me, we agreed on my hours of work and I was also offered counselling. As cancer patients we are covered by the disability act so that there is no discrimination so if you need time off for more ops then it shouldn't be a problem. I have had the word cosmetic used for my further ops but it's something that we need done as part of this horrible cancer nightmare, our bodies need to be repaired to help us physically and mentally. None of it is our choice in life so don't let anybody make you feel that it's just cosmetic and unimportant. I would speak to your manager at work who should be referring you to occ health through your hr system. I work for the local authority so the nhs should have similar procedures when it comes to this. look at it as occ health being your back up support And if you need to push for a result then do so, we shouldn't need to but sometimes We have no other choice? Good luck And keep us posted as to how you get on.  tilly xx

Posts.Content: Hi pat, I felt exactly the same after my op, I was so poorly with an infection and a cold that I just wanted to have a quiet time on the couch with just my partner looking after me, just for a short while anyway as, like you have had, the support I received was immense. Posts.Title: Tearful

Posts.Content: Hi carlie i had a masectomy with immediate reconstruction on 16 oct 2014, as I had 2 areas of calcification cells and lots of scattered cells i had no option but to have a masectomy. I remember feeling very scared if everything as at the time I didn't know what treatment lay ahead. However with the support of everyone around me and my BCN I tried to keepself positive and to accept that it had to be done. I kept myself very busy filling in every moment possible (we all know what it's like during the night though) I had to wait 6 weeks after my diagnosis for my op so by the time I had it I just wanted it over with. I also found coming on here was a huge help too  Good luck with your op tilly xx
Posts.Title: Scared & anxious

Posts.Content: I wasn't in that much pain, just a bit uncomfortable with the drains but they weren't in for too long. I tried to be very positive on the outsid but was actually just scared of everything. You're not being silly but actually very brave in trying to stay as positive as you can, I was scared of the anaesthetic too as I had never had any kind of operation or even stayed in hospital. The staff were wonderful though and I did feel very well looked after. when you go in to hospital they just take over and I had every step explained to me, the anaesthetist was chatting say and then the next thing I knew my nurse was waking me up.  I was lucky in that I could have an immediate reconstruction but after nearly a year it's still ongoing (had a few problems that delayed the process) I've still got a couple more ops to have but I try not to get stressed and take one day at a time. I know that's easier said than done though :-) tilly xx
Posts.Title: Scared & anxious

Posts.Content: Well done pat and you did the right thing going straifht to your doctor, I went a couple of times straight after my op when I thought there was problems and it just put my mind at rest. I had to wait a couple of months before I found out whether I needed chemo or not and that was with my oncologist. I tried to keep the anxiety at bay by keeping myself as occupied as possible and I always tried to be positive but I had a few "wobbles" too (still do now and again) and that's ok.   good luck for the 1 October :-) tilly x
